{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3156027,"name":"","username":"Wing","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wing/{size}/175245_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-02T18:00:31.774Z","cooked":"

I should begin by clarifying since theres essentially two layers to my question. The first part would just consist of how does object detection work using photonvision (such as detecting gamepieces like cubes or cones). Has anyone played around with it or have any prior experience they could comment on?

Secondly, which is my more specific query, would it be possible to tell the orientation of a flipped cone on the floor (the degrees its rotated by etc) using said object detection? If its possible I was thinking that a claw on a moveable wrist with a fair amount of degrees of freedom could potentially grab a flipped cone at any orientation without moving the chassis at all.

Im really interested in hearing what anyone has to say, whether it be providing help or just commenting on this.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2023-03-02T18:00:31.774Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":758,"reads":174,"readers_count":173,"score":3829.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":428687,"topic_slug":"detecting-object-orientation-using-limelight-photonvision","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51272,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Waffler"},"post_url":"/t/detecting-object-orientation-using-limelight-photonvision/428687/1","custom_user_title":"Waffler","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3156092,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-02T19:10:49.343Z","cooked":"
Wing:

The first part would just consist of how does object detection work using photonvision (such as detecting gamepieces like cubes or cones).

The basic pipeline is:

  1. Get a color image from the camera
  2. Identify which pixels match a certain filter on color and intensity
  3. Group the contiguous “match” pixels together
  4. Identify which group of matched pixels is most likely the target of interest
  5. Report the center and corners of the group of pixels that is atarget (in pixel X/Y)
  6. (optional) run some math to convert pixel XY coordinates into real-world spatial measurements, possibly involving the distortion the camera applies to the image.
Wing:

Secondly, which is my more specific query, would it be possible to tell the orientation of a flipped cone on the floor (the degrees its rotated by etc) using said object detection?

The question that’s at the crux of this problem - can you robustly pick out specific points on the object? Ex: can you identify where the tip and all four corners of the base of the code? Or maybe the circle of the radius of the open bottom of the cone?

If so, because you know the physical dimensions of the code, there is existing math that will allow you to calculate the real-world position and orientation of it.

However, this isn’t something that photonvision has built-in for detecting just yet. I’m not entirely certain what algorithm or class of algorithms would be best to solve it.

FWIW this dovetails well with apriltags - the reason the 3d orientation is easy to get from them is that it’s easy to detect where the corners of the black/white tag are at. It’s much less tractable when the yellow tip of the cone is the exact same color as the yellow base, and the two sometimes (but not always) overlap or occlude each other.

So i’ve been thinking about it and first off id say that the camera would probably be in the claw so that when the wrist is angled downwards the camera is looking at the cone from the top and not from the side. So realistically it would have 3 points to focus in on and then make a little rectangle thingy. Something like this maybe?

IMG_20230302_17215103621920×1440 129 KB

I know that openCV has its on ways of doing it like shown here but im a stranger to openCV and its java implementations within frc.

If you have constrained the problem such that you are always looking down from the top, and the object is a different color than the background, yes, there is a chance that could work. Check out the colored shape pipeline maybe , it can detect triangle-like groups of pixels.
